title: Sydney Tomsick
text:
Sydney Tomsick is a third-year Statistics and Data Science major at UCLA with a minor in Digital Humanities. She is passionate about deriving valuable insights through data and presenting her findings in creative and innovative ways. She also enjoys web design and user experience research. Outside of academic pursuits, Sydney loves to dance and is one of the directors of Synthesis Dance Theater, a dance club at UCLA.

title: Exploring Female Representation in MoMA
text:
My team and I created a website discussing the lack of female representation in art museums. We used this dataset created by the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) to make visualizations showing how female artist representation has changed in MoMA overtime both in the US and globally. Using our research, we discussed potential connections between changes in gender representation in MoMA and feminist movements taking place at the same time.

Our Research Questions

How did waves of feminism and American social movements of the mid-1900s affect the representation of American female artists in the MoMA collection? 
Beyond the U.S., how did global feminist movements relate to the ethnic diversity of female artists in the MoMA collection?



My Responsibilities
My main responsibility in this project was web design through WordPress. I also helped clean the data and create data visualizations.

title: Exploring Female Representation in MoMA
text:
About
My team and I created a websitediscussing the lack of female representation in art museums. We used the Artworks.csv dataset from this GitHub repository created by the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA). The dataset includes the title of every art piece acquired by the MoMA museum in New York since its opening, demographic information about the artist, the date the art piece was acquired, whether the art piece is currently on view, and many more variables. We used this data to make visualizations showing how female artist representation has changed in MoMA over time both in the US and globally. Using our research, we discussed potential connections between changes in gender representation in MoMA and feminist movements taking place at the same time.


Our Research Questions

How did waves of feminism and American social movements of the mid-1900s affect the representation of American female artists in the MoMA collection? 
Beyond the U.S., how did global feminist movements relate to the ethnic diversity of female artists in the MoMA collection?



My Role
My main responsibility for this project was web design through WordPress. I also helped clean the data and create data visualizations.

title: A Clinical Study: The Effect of Caffeine and Exercise on Attention
text:
About
Using a 2-way factorial design with interactions, I studied whether caffeine intake and exercise duration significantly impact attention span. Here is my written Report,
There were 9 experimental groups in total. The 2 factors each had 3 levels:

Caffeine intake: Green Tea (250mL), Coffee (250mL), Coffee (500mL)
Running distance: 100m, 1km, 5km

I used ANOVA to reveal whether caffeine intake, running distance, or their interaction had a statistically significant effect on attention span. I used Tukey’s test to reveal whether any individual group differed significantly from the others.

title: Kaggle Competition: Predicting Obesity Status
text:
About
My team and I were provided with a training and testing dataset containing 29 predictors of obesity status capturing aspects such as dietary habits, physical activity, water consumption, and family medical history. The outcome variable “obesity status” classified individuals as either “Obese” or “Not Obese”. We were tasked with predicting obesity status for the testing dataset and determining the most influential predictors. Here is my written Report.


Methods
First, we imputed the data using random forests to fill in missing values. Then, we tried multiple models to predict obesity status such as logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests. Our random forests model with 500 trees performed best, with a testing prediction accuracy of 99.943%.
We then found the most influential predictors using correlation analysis (point-biserial and Cramer’s V correlation) and variable importance from the random forests model.

title: Altadena and The Eaton Fire
text:
About
My team and I created a website in which we explore the impacts of the Eaton Fire on marginalized communities in Altadena. Our website compiles maps we created using ArcGIS and our narrative which discusses the history of discrimination within Altadena. To create our maps, we used various datasets such as the Cal Fire Damage Inspection (DINS) data, a layer within ArcGIS which shows how much damage each house and structure faced in the Eaton Fire. We also used HOLC grade data, the National Register of Historic Places, and US Census data.


Research Questions

How did the Eaton Fire damages affect homeowners in marginalized communities in Altadena, and what role did historical segregation policies play in shaping vulnerability to wildfire risks?
How did the Eaton Fire impact Altadena’s community both in terms of historical landmarks and cultural legacy? What does the loss of these spaces mean for the community’s future?

title: The Social Soundscape: How Social Media Impacts Music Popularity
text:
About
My team and I used this dataset with over 4000 observations. It contains the name, artist, album name, and release date of the songs with the most Spotify streams in 2024. It also contains the number of Spotify Streams, Youtube views, Youtube likes, TikTok views, and TikTok likes of each song, and information from other music streaming platforms (Apple music, Pandora, Soundcloud, etc.). You can find more information about each of the variables at this link. We used this dataset to answer the following research questions. Here is our Report and Poster.


Research Questions

Does the release month of a song impact its popularity?
Are certain genres of songs more popular on certain platforms?
Is there a correlation between a song’s popularity on TikTok vs. Spotify?



My Role
I was specifically responsible for cleaning the data and answering research question 1. I cleaned the data by removing duplicate observations, removing unnecessary columns, standardizing the release date column, adding a “Release.Month” column, ensuring each variable was the correct data type, and performing missing data imputation.
For research question 1, I checked the assumptions for ANOVA and found that the residuals were heavily skewed and did not follow a normal distribution. Therefore, I used the nonparametric Kruskal Wallis test to evaluate whether at least one release month had a statistically different distribution of Spotify streams compared to others. For the post-hoc analysis, I used the Wilcoxon Rank-Sum test with Bonferroni correction to evaluate which specific release months had a different distribution of Spotify Streams.

title: UX Design for Snagged
text:
About
I conceptualized and designed “Snagged”: an app for style-conscious thrifters who want to discover new thrift stores, rate and review their experiences, and share their journey with friends. My whole process of designing “Snagged” can be found on this website; from user interviews and personas to wireframes and the final design.

title: Client Project: A Statistical Analysis of the Informed Placement Process at UCLA
text:
About
This Statistical Analysis Paper was a client project for the UCLA English Department, which aimed to understand how self-assessments and demographic factors influence incoming students’ English placement outcomes. Using data from 980 students, we built logistic and linear regression models to examine how writing confidence and structural inequities affect placement results. We found that higher self-reported confidence reduced the need for a second evaluator, while underrepresented minority students were more likely to be placed in lower-level courses, pointing to potential disparities in the placement process.
